title: Cricket: How Aussies are faring in Major League Cricket
body:
3 minute read

Australia skipper Pat Cummins has joined the party at Major League Cricket as he features for a San Francisco Unicorns side well stacked with Baggy Greens stars.

Cummins has a number of fellow Aussies taking part in the 20-over competition in the United States, with Washington Freedom currently leading the way inspired by Steven Smith, Travis Head and Glenn Maxwell.

Freedom - 2.40 to secure the MLC title - have won all five of their completed fixtures, with a washout the only thing robbing them of a 100 per cent record, while Cummins features for a Unicorns outfit who lie second in the standings with three wins from five games.

Freedom march on thanks to Aussie batters

In the most recent fixture Washington saw off Texas Super Kings by 42 runs to maintain their unbeaten record, with Smith and Head both making half-centuries at the top of the order.

It's fair to say Head dominated the partnership as he was dismissed for 53, having added 59 for the first wicket with Smith, with Maxwell later smacking three sixes in his 34 and then taking three wickets with his off-spin.

Head (194) and Smith (191) have certainly been enjoying themselves with the bat, as they lie third and fourth respectively; in the runscorers' chart in MLC, with South African Faf du Plessis leading the way with 264 runs for Super Kings.

Du Plessis is one of two century-makers in MLC so far this season, with fellow South African Ryan Rickelton the other player to reach three figures, for Seattle Orcas.

Aussie pair back up Du Plessis

Playing alongside former Proteas skipper Du Plessis at Super Kings are Baggy Greens pair Marcus Stoinis and Aaron Hardie, with the former having made more of an impression with the ball than he has with the bat so far.

In fairness, neither player has excelled to date and both will want to deliver more for their side, with 6.00 Texas currently well-placed to ensure a top-four finish and a place in the play-offs - only two of the six teams miss out on the end-of-season finale.

Tim David has also yet to fire for reigning champions MI New York in his three appearances, while both Alex Carey and Adam Zampa have yet to feature for Los Angeles Knight Riders.

Left-arm quick Spencer Johnson has sparked for the 9.00 Knight Riders, however, taking eight wickets at 19.75 in his five games to date, although that wickets tally is one less than Maxwell has snapped up for Freedom.

Cummins adds to the Aussie mix

That leaves us with Unicorns, who have added Cummins to a roster which already features his fellow Aussies Matt Short, Josh Inglis and Jake Fraser-McGurk and who are 3.75 to be crowned champions.

Short has passed 50 twice in his four knocks so far this season in MLC, but neither Inglis nor Fraser-McGurk have made significant contributions to date, while Cummins has taken just one wicket across his two appearances.

He will want to help San Francisco make certain of a play-off place, with Unicorns having missed out during the inaugural MLC season last year, with New York eventually defeating Orcas by seven wickets in the final.

title: Major League Cricket 2024: Washington Freedom fall short against San Francisco Unicorns in a rain
body:
Washington Freedom lost to San Francisco Unicorns by six wickets in their rain-shortened final league stage match of the Major League Cricket 2024 season at Grand Prairie Stadium in Dallas on Monday.

Travis Head and captain Steve Smith jointly top-scored for us as we reached 174/3 in 15.3 overs before rain prematurely ended our batting essay. Smith scored 56 off 31 balls and his knock was laden with four sixes and five fours. Whereas Head hit three sixes and five boundaries for his 36-ball 56, his fourth straight fifty in the competition.

Chasing a revised target of 177 in 14 overs, the San Francisco Unicorns got to the target in just 13.4 overs. Sanjay Krishnamurthi remained unbeaten on 79 off 42 balls for SFU while Josh Inglis hit 45 from 17 balls.

Meanwhile, Andrew Tye finished as the top wicket-taker in the match with figures of 3/41.

Batting first, Head and Smith did what they have done throughout the season, by providing us a rollicking start. Smith took the role of the aggressor smashing three sixes and five fours in the powerplay as we raced to 70/0 after the first six overs, the fourth fifty-plus stand for the Aussies together this season.

Smith powered to a 25-ball fifty in the eighth over and soon the duo got to our first 100-run partnership in the history of MLC before the skipper departed. Head shifted gears to get to his half-century in just 34 balls continuing his purple patch this season.

Rachin Ravindra and Andries Gous kept the scoring rate high with an entertaining partnership of 33 off only 15 balls. Just as we were looking to go past the 200-run mark for the second consecutive game, rain halted proceedings, cutting short our batting essay with 27 balls remaining.

Akeal Hosein gave us a great start after the rain delay, striking with the first ball of the chase to send back Finn Allen. Andrew Tye dismissed the big fish, Jake Fraser-McGurk, leaving both openers back in the hut by the fifth over with the score at 45.

The experienced Tye brought us back into the match with two wickets in an over after Krishnamurthi and Inglis added 77 runs in just 30 balls for the third wicket. In the end, the San Francisco Unicorns chased down the target with two balls to spare.

Hassan Khan contributed a cameo of 32 from 11 balls, while Krishnamurthi remained unbeaten on 79. Apart from Tye, Hosein picked up 1/39 from his three overs.

However, the result had no bearing on the points table of MLC 2024 as we finished on top with 11 points from seven games after all our group engagements.

We will meet the San Francisco Unicorns again in the Qualifier of MLC 2024 at the Grand Prairie Stadium in Dallas on Thursday.

Washington Freedom vs San Francisco Unicorns MLC 2024 brief scores: WF 174/3 in 15.3 overs (Steve Smith 56, Travis Head 56, Corey Anderson 2/20) vs SFU 177/4 in 13.4 overs (Sanjay Krishnamurthi 79*, Josh Inglis 45, Andrew Tye 3/41, Akeal Hosein 1/39).

Washington Freedom lost by six wickets by DLS method.

title: Major League Cricket is on the rise in the US
body:
After the ICC Mens T20 World Cup thrilled American sports fans with top-tier cricket matches at venues in Florida, New York and Texas, Major League Cricket is gearing up for an exciting second season of progress.

Major League Cricket will conclude its 21-match season this week, culminating in a thrilling four-team play-off to crown a new champion. Despite having six teams spread across the country, all competitions are being held on dedicated cricket grounds in Texas and North Carolina. Remarkably, attendances are on track to surpass the impressive 70,000 fans who turned out for the inaugural season in 2023.

A key strategy Major League Cricket has employed to attract a broader audience is its media rights arrangement with Cricbuzz’s Willow, a specialist cricket channel. Willow has established partnerships with regional sports networks in each team’s local market, including Bally Sports SoCal for Los Angeles, Monumental Sports Network for Washington, DC, and NBC Sports Bay Area for San Francisco, among many others. This tactic mirrors Willow’s successful approach during the T20 World Cup, where it focused on increasing visibility.

In terms of finances, Major League Cricket operates within a salary cap of $1.15 million per team. While this figure is below the generous budgets seen in global leagues such as the Indian Premier League, which allows franchises to spend around $12 million annually, it remains competitive with leagues such as Cricket Australia ($2 million) and The Hundred ($1.3 million) in the UK.

Liam Plunkett, a bowler for the San Francisco Unicorns and member of the England team that won the 2019 Cricket World Cup, praises the quality and competitiveness of the competition. “The money is good. But the product is good too,” Plunkett notes, highlighting the high standard of play that attracts fans and players alike.

San Francisco’s signing of Australian national team captain Pat Cummins on a four-year contract ahead of the season was a major move that reflects the league’s ambition. Unicorns co-owner Anand Rajaraman reveals that such contracts have proven surprisingly feasible given the excitement surrounding the emerging US cricket market.

Looking ahead, the league has ambitious plans for expansion, aiming to establish stadiums in each team’s market and expand the schedule to 34 games by 2025. With the intention of increasing the number of franchises to 10, Major League Cricket is poised for continued growth and success in the American sports landscape.
